newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani cotton steady in selective trade.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani cotton steady in selective trade.

text.p: Pakistani cotton rates were unchanged on Sunday as spinners bought selectively, anticipating them to fall on increased supplies, dealers said.

They said the prices resisted any fall on news of a damage to the cotton crop by a virus attack and recent floods in the main growing central province of Punjab. But the rates could fall in the next few sessions as there were no credible reports of any substantial crop damage because of the virus or floods.
In the kerb market, the NIAB-78 variety of 1996/97 crop was traded in the range of 2,375 ($66.69) to 2,325 rupees per maund (37.32 kg), the dealers said.

The Karachi Cotton Association (KCA) said customs-cleared cotton exports had reached 1,824,676 375-lb bales by July 31, since the 1995/96 picking season began on September 1. Imports had reached 96,230 480-lb bales in the same period.
Sunday's official spot rates issued by the KCA in rupees per maund including a 10 percent sales tax:
